oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: T. G. Sheppard Interview - Biff Collie
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Recording of an interview with T. G. Sheppard (performer) conducted by Biff Collie.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: T. G. Sheppard; Biff Collie
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:tableOfContents: (00:00) T. G. Sheppard recalls his first memorable Christmas -- (01:07) Sheppard tells about how people believe he's forgotten them with his fame -- (02:04) Sheppard tells a story about being pulled over by an officer that recognized him -- (03:15) Sheppard recalls how he started playing the saxophone in high school, and how he was moved to flag carrier -- (04:24) Sheppard parallels "Smooth Sailin'" to a feeling of comfort -- (06:29) Sheppard recalls his first impressions of elementary school and his childhood best-friend -- (09:46) "I Loved 'Em Every One" is described by Sheppard to be a signature song -- (10:10) Sheppard reflects on his disassociation to the other students in high school -- (12:02) Sheppard says "Devil in the Bottle" caused his career to take off -- (12:18) Sheppard reflects on how he has had a number of names, and Sheppard reflects on the creativity allowed in his industry -- (15:17) Sheppard recalls "One For the Money" as a record that was 'magical' -- (16:01) Sheppard recalls his time as a record producer, and Sheppard describes how Waylon Jennings affected Sheppard's career -- (18:45) Sheppard describes his feeling while being a flag carrier, and Sheppard recalls pawning his saxophone -- (19:51) "In Over My Heart" is described by Sheppard to be for his fans instead of for the radio companies -- (20:57) Sheppard tells about a time he met Elvis Presley at a roller rink; additionally, Sheppard recalls how Presley continuously attempted to give him gifts -- (27:57) Sheppard recalls how he began his friendship with Clint Eastwood -- (30:27) 'Go ahead, make my day' is told by Sheppard to have been a line that inspired his friendship to Eastwood -- (30:59) Sheppard reveals that Merle Haggard, Kenny Rogers, and George Jones are some of his favorite artists -- (32:08) Sheppard says that the Howdy Doody Show was his favorite television show -- (33:15) Sheppard tells tales of his favorite foods -- (34:46) Sheppard reflects on his racing hobby -- (36:30) "Last Cheater's Waltz" is told by Sheppard to be a lasting song -- (37:08) Sheppard recalls how he came up with the name for Moon Mountain in Gatlinburg, Tennessee -- (40:48) Sheppard describes "Faking Love" vocalist Karen Brooks -- (41:20) Sheppard describes his involvement with Guitars and Cadillacs -- (42:59) Sheppard explains the uniqueness of Conway Twitty -- (43:50) Sheppard explains his change of opinion, on being controversial, for Twitty -- (45:33) Sheppard describes the feeling of fear of losing -- (47:19) Sheppard reflects on coming to terms with people disliking him -- (48:13) "Finally" is told, by Sheppard, to be his solo performance -- (48:45) Sheppard reflects on his long recording career and his future aspirations -- (50:16) "It's Party Time" is revealed to be the number one programmed song for the year -- (50:55) Sheppard says that keys measure success for him
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:subject: Sheppard, T. G.; Collie, Biff;
